"Today's sports commentators should be told that they are at a high level"
COMMENT: "The reporter need not be bad even if the match is there".
03 Nov 2019, 08:36 by Ola Bernhus
The quote came from BjÃ¸rge Lillelien in 1981. Norway had lost 1-3 against Finland in a hysterically exciting and well-played match. Only the day after, when we read the interviews and papers in the newspapers, did we learn that it had been downright boring, and Norway had played miserably.
I was in Dagbladet then, and we had fun over BjÃ¸rge's, to say the least, unreliable radio talk. I met him in Stortingsgaten the day after, and he explained what he meant by what sports on radio should be. Entertainment.
In a treasure of a book - Gold to Norway by commentator veteran Arve Fuglum - we can read a lot about BjÃ¸rge Lillelien, but also about the other legends. Because there are legends we talk about, whether they were good or bad, because for years they came into our living room through radio and TV and did the sport really.
Knut Th. Gleditsch, Karen-Marie Ellefsen, Knut BjÃ¸rnsen and BjÃ¸rge Lillelien adorn the cover, it could be others they are all with. They splash out on us in a book where sound is turned into text so we almost hear every hoot.

What has been less talked about - of course, it would have been sad otherwise - is how the whole was. Everyday.
Worth boasting about
Not all gold glittered, not before either. Here I would say: On the contrary.
Today's sports commentators should be told that they are at a high level. On average, higher than those we knew from the childhood of TV commentary. Many can compare with the legends.


Knut Th. Gleditsch was one of the most well-known voices, both at NRK and Viasat.olf Rolf Ã˜hman

They are so prepared to the smallest detail, so full of joy to give us an experience, so "advance in the shoes", which is an expression some of them suddenly use. NRK is still on top in what is still their sport.
But there is just as much pleasure in following the football broadcasts of Viasat, Eurosport and TV2, with informed commentators in the studio and active, heroic commentators on the matches themselves.
We feel absolutely safe when TV 2-pair Ã˜yvind Alsaker and Petter Myhre follow the ball (although we wish the outstanding Alsaker would let us enjoy the seconds after a score before squeezing in).
It's great to hear Joacim Jonsson in the Eurosport studio cutting Norwegian football into small pieces when it's in place, or when Rune Bratseth brings in madness and "listen here" when it comes to stays in Viasat studio. As examples.

SET THIS? King sunk United - afterwards, SolskjÃ¦r took self-criticism



TV 2's Petter Myhre (t.v.) and Ã˜yvind Alsaker during the Russia World Cup.ğŸ“· Olof Andersson, TV 2.

All this and much more is sports journalism at a level where it is premature to want more, whether it is descriptions or analyzes. Maybe a little less, but we can decide for ourselves. Still, it is possible to turn down the sound when we want peace and trust in our own eyes.
More funny than annoying
But now we hear the objections. You your age, you must respond to the vocabulary? Yes, all the time. It is roared and thundered more than the language can withstand, and there is little understanding that a sober adjective / verb usually strikes stronger than a roar. And I smile a little when I hear how a single word is suddenly used by everyone, as if a decree had been issued from the Ministry of Culture.


Joacim Jonsson comments on Eurosport.ğŸ“· Svein Ove EkornesvÃ¥g / NTB scanpix

As on command, everyone began to say "healthy bones", directly translated from English as most otherwise.
